summary: Arenaviruses have a negative-sense, bisegmented RNA genome comprised of two single-stranded segments with an ambisense coding strategy. the small (S) segment encodes the nucleoprotein (NP) and the glycoprotein (GP), while the large (L) segment encodes the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (L) and the matrix protein Z (9–15). GP forms spikes on the exterior of the virion, NP and L together with the genome form the ribonucleoprotein complex. arenaviruses are enveloped and enter cells through receptor-mediated endocytosis. GP triggers fusion of the viral envelope with the endosomal membrane, releasing viral ribonucleoproteins into the cytoplasm. the release of arenavirus virions has traditionally been thought to be mediated by Z's recruitment of the cellular endosomal sorting complex required for transport (ESCRT) the prototypic Old World arenavirus, lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus (LCMV) requires both a functional late domain and ESCRT complex for the production of defective interfering particles, but not for infectious virus particles. functional studies identified several host proteins that are required for arenavirus propagation. a functional ESCRT complex is required for the production of infectious JUNV particles. DISCUSSION Viruses hijack host machinery to complete the various stages of their life cycles. 5-ethynyl-1--d-ribofuranosylimidazole-4-carboxamide (EICAR) treatment inhibits arenavirus production (63) this finding could indicate that arenaviruses recruit IMPDH2 as a means to support the processes of genome replication and transcription. however, IMPDH2 depletion inhibits JUNV VLP release. several vesicular trafficking proteins, including members of the Ras superfamily, were enriched in Z VLPs and/or JUNV virions. a parallel siRNA screen found ARF1 necessary for optimal LCMV propagation, suggesting that it may be broadly important for arenavirus infection (62). the presence of Rab proteins in virions suggests that some of these Rab proteins may have a role in late steps of the virus life cycle (i.e., assembly and budding) the presence of Rab proteins in virions suggests that some of these Rab proteins may have a role in late steps of the virus life cycle. the arenavirus matrix protein drives the budding and release of virus particles at the plasma membrane (17, 41, 42) ESCRT-I complexes are thought to be involved in the recruitment of ESCRT-I complexes. ESCRT proteins, including the ESCRT-I proteins TSG101 and VPS28, as well as the ESCRT accessory protein VPS4B, have been identified in virions of other viruses containing the P(T/S)AP late domain. Knockdown of ESCRT-I protein TSG101 results in decreased VLP production for LCMV and LASV (17, 42), but not Lujo virus (41, 47, 94).
